results.title: China’s Vow to Reduce Abortions Sparks Public Worries
results.abstract: The short mention in a sweeping health plan lacked specifics, but it set off concerns in a country with a history of intrusive reproductive policies.

results.title: As Tunisia’s President Cements One-Man Rule, Opposition Grows
results.abstract: In his latest step to consolidate power, President Kais Saied set up a system under which he will essentially govern the country by decree, bypassing the Constitution.

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia at the Carthage Palace, his official residence, in 2019. Mr. Saied froze Parliament, fired the prime minister and seized power on July 25.
multimedia.copyright: Khaled Nasraoui/picture alliance, via Getty Images)

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia at the Carthage Palace, his official residence, in 2019. Mr. Saied froze Parliament, fired the prime minister and seized power on July 25.

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia at the Carthage Palace, his official residence, in 2019. Mr. Saied froze Parliament, fired the prime minister and seized power on July 25.

results.title: Five Years After Peace Deal, Colombia Is Running Out of Time, Experts Say
results.abstract: A treaty with rebels in 2016 called for the end of a decades-long war. But that is not the same as achieving peace, and the window for doing so may be closing.
results.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Towns like La Paz, in Colombia, remain under the control of armed groups five years after Colombia’s government signed a peace treaty with the largest of them.

results.title: Women Enslaved by ISIS Say They Did Not Consent to a Film About Them
results.abstract: The acclaimed documentary “Sabaya” portrays the rescue of Yazidi women sexually enslaved by the Islamic State terrorist group. But many of the traumatized women said they never agreed to be in the film.

des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

results.title: Intrigue Deepens at U.N. Over Myanmar and Afghanistan

results.title: ‘Every Day Is Frightening’: Working for the Top U.S. Employer Amid Covid
results.abstract: As offices debate the merits and logistics of reopening, a parallel sphere of workers like Peter Naughton, a Walmart cashier, seem to inhabit another world. Often their jobs just got really hard.

multimedia.caption: Peter Naughton is a cashier and self-checkout host in Baton Rouge, La., at Walmart, the country’s largest private employer. He fears going to work — but also the idea of missing it.

results.title: Jonathan Mirsky, Journalist and Historian of China, Dies at 88

results.title: Five Killed in West Bank Shootouts
results.abstract: The Israeli military said the five were killed during raids to arrest members of a Hamas network planning terrorist attacks against Israeli civilians.

results.title: Voting ends in Germany in a tight race.
results.abstract: The voting is done, and exit polling throughout the day has suggested that the Social Democrats and the Christian Democratic Union are very close.

multimedia.caption: Early-morning voters in Munich. In a sign that the closest election in years had mobilized voters, turnout was expected to surpass the 76 percent recorded in 2017, when the last national elections were held.
multimedia.copyright: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

results.title: Théoneste Bagosora, a Mastermind of Rwanda Genocide, Dies at 80
results.abstract: Mr. Bagosora was convicted of genocide for ordering a massacre in the capital and the killing of top officials, including the prime minister.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Théoneste Bagosora, a lead figure in the Rwandan genocide, at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, in 2008.

results.title: South Korea will start giving vaccine boosters amid a surge in Covid cases.
results.abstract: The country has seen a spike in infections after Chuseok, a three-day holiday celebrating the fall harvest.

results.title: In-person turnout is lower than in 2017, but mail-in ballots may boost overall numbers.

multimedia.caption: By 2 p.m., 37 percent of eligible voters had cast ballots in person, election officials said, down from 41 percent during the same period in 2017.

results.title: Swiss Voters Approve Law Allowing Same-Sex Marriages
results.abstract: The legislation, endorsed in a referendum, will also allow same-sex couples to use sperm banks and to adopt children for the first time.
des_facet: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

multimedia.caption: A Pride parade this month in Zurich. The referendum result has been hailed as a milestone for the L.G.B.T.Q. community in Switzerland.
multimedia.copyright: Michael Buholzer/Keystone, via Associated Press

results.title: These are the leading candidates for the chancellery.
results.abstract: In Germany, political parties name their candidates for chancellor before campaigning begins.
results.byline: By Katrin Bennhold, Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze

multimedia.caption: Annalena Baerbock in Duisburg, western Germany, in August. “Change requires courage, and change is on the ballot on Sept. 26,” she has said.
